abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is rated as
            unsatisfactory. Key lessons learned include: 1)
            Macroeconomic risks such as policies towards the supply and
            pricing of bitumen and the declared self-sufficiency and
            consequent import restrictions of the government were not
            sufficiently considered in the project design. 2) In
            parallel with the economic decline and political turmoil, an
            institutional decline was experienced in the road sector in
            Nigeria with a particular severe impact on the project.
            Fundamental restructuring is required to achieve
            sustainability. 3) Reliable supply of bitumen is crucial for
            the execution of a road project. 4) To achieve sustainable
            finance of road maintenance, the road users must be involved
            in the management of the roads. 5) The Bank should continue
            to support Road Vision 2000, which aims at fundamental
            reform of road management in Nigeria. 6) Possible future
            support by the Bank could be in the form of guarantees to
            private sector concessionaires for the management of highly
            trafficked roads and investments in the recovery of the
            badly deteriorated road network. 6) Unless a fundamental
            reform of the management of the roads can be achieved with
            true stakeholder ownership, the Bank should not finance
            further road projects, but should focus on the promotion of
            the reform process.
